title: Covalent Bonding
description: Understand how covalent bonds form through electron sharing and their molecular properties
subject: Chemistry
achievementDescription: Master covalent bonding and molecular geometry

text.introduction: Covalent bonding occurs when atoms share electrons to achieve stable electron configurations. This sharing creates molecules with specific geometries and properties that differ significantly from ionic compounds.

sections.title: Formation of Covalent Bonds
sections.content: Covalent bonds form when nonmetal atoms share electrons. The shared electrons are attracted to both nuclei, creating a bonding molecular orbital. Single bonds involve one shared pair, double bonds involve two pairs, and triple bonds involve three pairs. Bond strength increases with the number of shared electron pairs.

sections.title: Lewis Structures and Formal Charge
sections.content: Lewis structures show bonding and nonbonding electrons in molecules. The octet rule states that atoms tend to form bonds until surrounded by eight valence electrons. Formal charge helps determine the best Lewis structure by minimizing charges and placing negative charges on the most electronegative atoms.

sections.title: VSEPR Theory and Molecular Geometry
sections.content: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory predicts molecular shapes based on electron pair repulsion. Electron pairs arrange themselves to minimize repulsion, creating specific geometries: linear, trigonal planar, tetrahedral, trigonal bipyramidal, and octahedral. Lone pairs occupy more space than bonding pairs.

sections.title: Polarity and Intermolecular Forces
sections.content: Molecular polarity depends on bond polarity and molecular geometry. Polar molecules have dipole moments and experience stronger intermolecular forces. Van der Waals forces include London dispersion forces, dipole-dipole interactions, and hydrogen bonding. These forces determine physical properties like boiling point and solubility.

questions.question: What is the molecular geometry of methane (CH4)?
questions.explanation: Methane has four bonding pairs and no lone pairs around carbon, resulting in tetrahedral geometry with 109.5Â° bond angles.

questions.question: Which intermolecular force is strongest?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonding is the strongest intermolecular force among the Van der Waals forces, occurring when H is bonded to F, O, or N.

exercises.title: Lewis Structures and Geometry
exercises.instructions: Draw Lewis structures and predict molecular geometries for: H2O, CO2, NH3, and SF6. Include bond angles and identify polar molecules.
exercises.hint: Count valence electrons, apply the octet rule, use VSEPR theory for geometry, and consider electronegativity differences for polarity.

scenarioChallenges.title: Ghana's Pharmaceutical Industry and Molecular Design
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Ghana is developing its pharmaceutical industry to produce medications locally. Understanding molecular geometry and bonding is crucial for drug design and efficacy.
tasks: Explain how molecular shape affects drug-receptor interactions in the human body
Describe why water solubility is important for many medications and how polarity affects this
Analyze how traditional medicinal plants in Ghana might contain molecules with specific geometries for biological activity
learningObjectives: Connect molecular geometry to biological activity
Appreciate the molecular basis of traditional medicine
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Ghana has a rich tradition of medicinal plants and is working to develop local pharmaceutical manufacturing to reduce dependence on imports.
